dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we've been talking a lot about inflation lately, right? But what's really interesting is this idea that policymakers, um, haven't quite acknowledged deglobalization's role in all of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we've been talking a lot about inflation lately, right? But what's really interesting is this idea that policymakers, um, haven't quite acknowledged deglobalization's role in all of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But policymakers have yet to acknowledge its contribution to global inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's like, a huge elephant in the room, isn't it? For decades, globalization, uh, really kept prices down. Cheaper labor, cheaper production costs, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's like, a huge elephant in the room, isn't it? For decades, globalization, uh, really kept prices down. Cheaper labor, cheaper production costs, all that good stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Globalization acted as a deflationary force by reducing labor and production costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But now, we're seeing the reverse. Deglobalization means, like, higher tariffs, more trade barriers...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But now, we're seeing the reverse. Deglobalization means, like, higher tariffs, more trade barriers...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Likewise, the main features of deglobalization higher tariffs and other trade barriers, together with a shift from global to regional trade flows are known drivers of inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] ...and a shift away from those big global supply chains to more regional ones. Which, inherently, is just more expensive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...and a shift away from those big global supply chains to more regional ones. Which, inherently, is just more expensive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Likewise, the main features of deglobalization higher tariffs and other trade barriers, together with a shift from global to regional trade flows are known drivers of inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, you see it in the numbers. Core goods inflation in the US, for example, it shot up from under two percent in early 2021 to, like, six percent by mid-2022. That's a huge jump.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, you see it in the numbers. Core goods inflation in the U S, for example, it shot up from under two percent in early twenty twenty one to, like, six percent by mid twenty twenty two. That's a huge jump.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is no surprise, then, that core goods inflation in the United States has increased sharply, from less than 2% at the start of 2021 to 6% in mid-2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just tariffs. You've got these ongoing supply-chain issues, like, thanks to China's zero-COVID policy and, uh, Russia's war in Ukraine. Those are just keeping food, fuel, and manufactured goods prices high.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just tariffs. You've got these ongoing supply-chain issues, like, thanks to China's zero-C O V I D policy and, uh, Russia's war in Ukraine. Those are just keeping food, fuel, and manufactured goods prices high.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now, however, ongoing supply-chain constraints related to Chinas strict zero-COVID policy and Russias war in Ukraine are expected to continue to raise the prices of food, fuel, and manufactured goods over the short and medium term.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then you throw in geopolitical tensions, too. It just feels like higher input costs are becoming a permanent feature of this, um, deglobalizing world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you throw in geopolitical tensions, too. It just feels like higher input costs are becoming a permanent feature of this, um, deglobalizing world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More broadly, heightened geopolitical tensions threaten to make higher input costs a fixture of a deglobalizing world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's making companies rethink everything. They're prioritizing resilience over just cheap production, which means, like, a lot of capital flowing back to the US. Which, ironically, could also push up prices here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's making companies rethink everything. They're prioritizing resilience over just cheap production, which means, like, a lot of capital flowing back to the U S. Which, ironically, could also push up prices here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As interest rates rise and supply chains remain vulnerable, US companies are favoring resilience over low production costs, leading to massive capital repatriation. ... In a deglobalizing economy, more investment capital would flow back to the US, leading to a higher volume of dollars chasing US assets and putting more upward pressure on prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, true. More dollars chasing US assets. Plus, if we have more barriers to migration, that could drive up labor costs too, right? Less access to top global talent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, true. More dollars chasing U S assets. Plus, if we have more barriers to migration, that could drive up labor costs too, right? Less access to top global talent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Barriers to migration would make it harder for US companies to attract top global talent and drive up labor costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. But, um, what really strikes me is the lack of coordination on a global scale. Remember 2008? There was a coordinated monetary response. Now? It's like every country for itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. But, um, what really strikes me is the lack of coordination on a global scale. Remember two thousand eight? There was a coordinated monetary response. Now? It's like every country for itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike the coordinated monetary response to the 2008 global financial crisis, policymakers in the worlds major economies seem to believe that every country must fend for itself in the fight against todays inflationary surge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild. The G7 leaders, they've pledged to monitor inflation, but no real *coordinated* action to combat it. In fact, some argue their sanctions against Russia have actually worsened inflationary pressures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild. The G seven leaders, they've pledged to monitor inflation, but no real coordinated action to combat it. In fact, some argue their sanctions against Russia have actually worsened inflationary pressures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While G7 leaders have pledged to monitor global inflation, they have not announced measures to combat soaring prices in a coordinated manner. On the contrary, the one recent coordinated policy action G7 countries undertook sanctions against Russia has arguably worsened inflationary pressures, by increasing supply-chain interruptions and spurring a spike in fuel prices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Which, like, makes sense, right? Supply chain interruptions, spiking fuel prices... it's a direct consequence. And then, when the big central banks hike rates, they essentially export inflation to smaller countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, like, makes sense, right? Supply chain interruptions, spiking fuel prices... it's a direct consequence. And then, when the big central banks hike rates, they essentially export inflation to smaller countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When major central banks hike interest rates, they export inflation to smaller countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The US dollar rising against the pound, the euro, the yen... it just means higher import costs for those countries whose currencies have weakened.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The U S dollar rising against the pound, the euro, the yen... it just means higher import costs for those countries whose currencies have weakened.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Aggressive monetary tightening in the US has already led the dollar to rise against the pound, breach parity with the euro, and reach a 20-year high against the yen, propelling higher import-led inflation in countries whose currencies have weakened.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, what does that mean for us, then? For the Fed? It feels like they're trying to stamp out inflation, but without addressing this bigger picture of deglobalization...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what does that mean for us, then? For the Fed? It feels like they're trying to stamp out inflation, but without addressing this bigger picture of deglobalization...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The Fed's rate hikes will help with demand, sure, but policymakers also need to, um, really devise strategies that mitigate the impact of this new deglobalized world. Otherwise, we're looking at higher inflation for longer than we'd like.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The Fed's rate hikes will help with demand, sure, but policymakers also need to, um, really devise strategies that mitigate the impact of this new deglobalized world. Otherwise, we're looking at higher inflation for longer than we'd like.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Feds current efforts to stamp out inflation by hiking interest rates and shrinking its balance sheet will reduce demand and thus help curb price growth. But policymakers must also devise measures that mitigate the impact of todays deglobalizing world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a much more complex challenge than just, you know, raising interest rates. This is a fundamental shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a much more complex challenge than just, you know, raising interest rates. This is a fundamental shift.
